title: 4-Cycles and Minimum Degree
content:
A **4-cycle** (Câ‚„) is a cycle on 4 vertices: a-b-c-d-a. It's the simplest even cycle and appears throughout graph theory.

**Minimum degree** is the smallest vertex degree in a graph. High minimum degree forces certain substructures to appearâ€”this is a central theme in extremal graph theory.

**The question**: What minimum degree guarantees a Câ‚„ must exist?

title: The 4-Cycle Graph
content:
**C4** is the 4-cycle graph on Fin 4 (vertices 0, 1, 2, 3).

Adjacency is defined by: vertex i is adjacent to vertex j iff they differ by 1 modulo 4.

Edges: 0-1, 1-2, 2-3, 3-0.

**Loopless proof**: We use `fin_cases i` to check all 4 verticesâ€”none is adjacent to itself.
mathContext: Formally: `Adj i j â†” (i.val + 1) % 4 = j.val âˆ¨ (j.val + 1) % 4 = i.val`

title: Containing a 4-Cycle
content:
**containsC4 V G** says the graph G on vertices V contains a 4-cycle.

Formally: there exists an injective function f: Fin 4 â†’ V such that whenever i,j are adjacent in C4, f(i) and f(j) are adjacent in G.

This is the standard notion of subgraph embedding via graph homomorphism.
mathContext: We require injectivity to ensure the 4 vertices map to 4 distinct vertices of G (no 'collapsed' cycles).

title: The Threshold Function f(n)
mathContext: Defined using `sInf` over natural numbers. The function is noncomputable because checking all graphs is undecidable.

title: Ramsey Connection
content:
**ramseyConnection** states the relationship between f(n) and the Ramsey number R(Câ‚„, K_{1,n}).

The Ramsey number R(Câ‚„, K_{1,n}) is the minimum m such that every graph on m vertices either contains Câ‚„ or has a vertex of degree â‰¥ n (a 'star' K_{1,n}).

**The equivalence**: f(m) â‰¤ m - n iff every m-vertex graph contains Câ‚„ or has a high-degree vertex.

This reformulation connects the degree threshold problem to Ramsey theory.
mathContext: The star graph K_{1,n} has one central vertex connected to n leaves. It's the complement of the Câ‚„ constraint in Ramsey terms.

title: Weaker Conjecture
content:
**WeakerConjecture** asks: Is f 'almost monotone'?

Formally: âˆƒ c such that for all m > n â‰¥ 4, f(m) + c > f(n).

This allows f to occasionally decrease, but by at most a constant c. If strict monotonicity fails, this weaker version might still hold.
mathContext: The bound c would be absoluteâ€”not depending on n or m. This is a common pattern when strict monotonicity is hard to prove.
